question: A tracheostomised patient, with poex tracheostomy tube, in the ward, developed sudden complete blockage of the tube. Which of the following is best next step in the management?
exp: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube is best next step in the management in the above case -Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate is done to avoid the blockage. -Suction of the tube with saline can't be used when there's a complete obstruction. - Jet ventilation is done below the level of larynx, when we're operating on the larynx.
opa: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube
opb: Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate

question: A patient with ____________ is a candidate for a supraglottic paial laryngectomy.
exp: Paial laryngectomy also known as Conservative laryngectomy - done to preserve the voice 1. Supraglottic Laryngectomy - removing half of the thyroid cailage Supraglottic Laryngectomy T1, 2, or 3 if only by preepiglottic space invasion Mobile cords No anterior commisure involvement FEV1>50% No tongue base disease past circumvallate papillae Apex of pyriform sinus not involved Supracricoid Laryngectomy - Thyroid cailage is completely removed - Crico-hyoid epiglottopexy
opa: A T2 lesion of the right aryepiglottic fold, a right false vocal cord, and impaired mobility of the true vocal cord
opb: A lesion of the laryngeal surface of the epiglottis below the hyoid bone with evidence of preepiglottic space invasion on computed tomography
opc: A lesion of the epiglottis, vallecula, and 1-cm, unilateral extension to the tongue base
opd: An invasive lesion of the false vocal cord that is found to extend significantly into the ventricle at the time of surgical endoscopy
